context: As argued previously by one of us (Brown), since the kynurenine pathway is stimulated by oxygen at oxygen-requiring enzymes, (including quinolinic acid-producing 3HAO), hyperbaric oxygen induced convulsions might result from the accumulation of the powerful excitogen, quinolinic acid. Additionally, recovery from a convulsion episode routinely occurs in hyperbaric oxygen. This may be explained by oxygen poisoning of 3HAO (as shown in Fig. 2) which requires a few min but then would result in decreased product (quinolinic acid) formation. Alternatively, recovery from convulsions might result from an increase production of the NMDA antagonist kynurenic acid by the kynurenine pathway. Kynurenic acid production logically would be increased via stimulation of indole amine 2,3-dioxygenase by oxygen and through build-up of its substrate kynurenine because of pathway inhibition at 3HAO. The brain concentration of 3HAA is not known precisely but like related kynurenine pathway intermediates it may be near 1 μM in the physiologically normal brain. However, the 3HAA concentration at the intracellular brain site of 3HAO and how it may vary (possibly increase) during oxygen poisoning of the kynurenine pathway during HBO, is unknown.
